subject: petrology
raw:
Mineral assemblages, texture analysis, geochemical signatures. <[silence]> Rock classification, metamorphic processes, magmatic differentiation. <[silence]>

Petrology is the scientific study of rocks, focusing on their origin, composition, and structure. <[silence]> It is divided into three main branches: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic petrology. <[silence]> Igneous petrology examines rocks formed from molten magma, analyzing processes such as crystallization and cooling rates. <[silence]> Sedimentary petrology investigates rocks formed from sediment deposition, emphasizing grain size, sorting, and cementation. <[silence]> Metamorphic petrology explores rocks that have undergone transformation due to pressure, temperature, and chemical changes. <[silence]>

Petrologists employ various techniques to study rocks, including microscopic examination, X-ray diffraction, and electron microprobe analysis. <[silence]> These methods allow for detailed investigation of mineral composition and texture, providing insights into the history and conditions of rock formation. <[silence]> Geochemical analysis further aids in understanding the elemental makeup and isotopic ratios within rocks, revealing information about the Earth's interior processes. <[silence]> 

Through petrology, scientists gain a deeper understanding of geological history and the dynamic processes shaping the Earth. <[silence]> This field contributes to resource exploration, environmental studies, and hazard assessment. <[silence]> Three related subjects are mineralogy, geochemistry, and tectonics.
